title: How to Make Cheese Soup

steps.headline: Place the heavy-based saucepan or soup pot onto the stovetop.
steps.description: Add the butter and heat over medium heat until it melts. Then add the diced carrots, onions and celery. Sweat for 5 to 10 minutes in the melted butter, or until they soften. Stir occasionally.

steps.headline: Sift the flour over the softened vegetables in the pot.
steps.description: Stir constantly for the next 2 to 3 minutes, as the mixture thickens.

steps.headline: Pour the chicken stock in gradually, stirring all the while.
steps.description: Bring to the boil and continue to stir. Once it reaches boiling point, reduce to a low simmer. Add the minced garlic and bay leaf.

steps.headline: Cover the pot.
steps.description: Allow to simmer on low for 30 minutes. Check periodically.

steps.headline: Turn the heat off.
steps.description: Fish out the bay leaf and set aside. Pour in the heavy cream and stir through. Using an immersion blender, blend the ingredients together. Always allow the mixture to cool down before blending. A conventional blender can be used, you'll just need to transfer the soup from the pot into the blender and back again.

steps.headline: Add the cheese to the soup.
steps.description: Do this gradually, and stir it in until melted before adding the next handful.

steps.headline: Add the Marsala, Worcestershire sauce and hot sauce.
steps.description: Stir through. Add the ground white pepper to taste, stirring through. At this stage, you might also determine whether or not the soup requires more salt; add some if necessary.

steps.headline: Warm the soup a little if needed.
steps.description: This isn't necessary unless you consider it needs to be warmer. Heat very gently over a low heat if warming some more.

steps.headline: Ladle the soup into four bowls.
steps.description: Serve immediately. The soup can be garnished with a sprig of parsley or sprinkle some Parmesan cheese over the top for added cheesiness. This goes well with crusty bread slices.

steps.headline: Add the butter to the large saucepan.
steps.description: Add the onions and sauté until softened.

steps.headline: Add the flour, salt, garlic powder and ground pepper to the sautéed onions.
steps.description: Stir together to form a smooth paste. Once a paste has formed, start adding the milk in small amounts, stirring constantly to combine the flour mix and milk. Each time it thickens, add a little more milk until it has all been added. The final mixture should be thickened and bubbling.

steps.headline: Pour the broth into the small saucepan.
steps.description: Bring to a boil, then drop to a simmer.

steps.headline: Add the shredded carrot and chopped celery to the boiled broth.
steps.description: Simmer for 5 minutes, or until the vegetables have softened.

steps.headline: Transfer the broth mix to the flour mix.
steps.description: Stir together to blend well. Add the shredded cheeses to this mixture and stir over a low heat, until melted in. The soup should be a thickened, liquid mixture. Do not boil the soup once the cheese has been added.

steps.headline: Remove from the heat.
steps.description: Pour the soup into four different bowls. Finish with a few chopped chives as a garnish, if desired.

steps.headline: Toast the stale bread slices.
steps.description: Spread butter over them. Sprinkle generously with the grated cheese. Set aside.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion rings in a little of the olive oil.
steps.description: Remove from the heat and set aside.

steps.headline: Make a single layer of the cheese-covered toast slices in the cast iron pot.
steps.description: Over this layer, arrange a layer of the sautéed onion rings. Then place another single layer of the bread pieces. Cover with chopped, peeled tomatoes. Finish with another layer of sautéed onions. Add a little bit more of the tomatoes and sprinkle in some more grated cheese.

steps.headline: Gently press down on the mixture to make space for the stock.
steps.description: Then pour the stock into it through a carefully placed funnel. Pour very gently and carefully so as to cause the stock to go below the ingredients; the other ingredients should not be covered by the stock.

steps.headline: Place the cast iron pot onto the stovetop.
steps.description: Do not cover. Allow to simmer for 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Place in the oven and cook for one hour in a medium hot oven.
steps.description: Check now and then; add more stock if needed, using a funnel again. It is important to keep the level of stock constant.

steps.headline: Remove from the oven.
steps.description: Serve into six different dishes, taking care not to swamp the ingredients in liquid. Serve immediately.

text: Cheese Soup Place the heavy-based saucepan or soup pot onto the stovetop. Add the butter and heat over medium heat until it melts. Then add the diced carrots, onions and celery. Sweat for 5 to 10 minutes in the melted butter, or until they soften. Stir occasionally. Sift the flour over the softened vegetables in the pot. Stir constantly for the next 2 to 3 minutes, as the mixture thickens. Pour the chicken stock in gradually, stirring all the while. Bring to the boil and continue to stir. Once it reaches boiling point, reduce to a low simmer. Add the minced garlic and bay leaf. Cover the pot. Allow to simmer on low for 30 minutes. Check periodically. Turn the heat off. Fish out the bay leaf and set aside. Pour in the heavy cream and stir through. Using an immersion blender, blend the ingredients together. Always allow the mixture to cool down before blending. A conventional blender can be used, you'll just need to transfer the soup from the pot into the blender and back again. Add the cheese to the soup. Do this gradually, and stir it in until melted before adding the next handful. Add the Marsala, Worcestershire sauce and hot sauce. Stir through. Add the ground white pepper to taste, stirring through. At this stage, you might also determine whether or not the soup requires more salt; add some if necessary. Warm the soup a little if needed. This isn't necessary unless you consider it needs to be warmer. Heat very gently over a low heat if warming some more. Ladle the soup into four bowls. Serve immediately. The soup can be garnished with a sprig of parsley or sprinkle some Parmesan cheese over the top for added cheesiness. This goes well with crusty bread slices. Quick Cheese Soup Add the butter to the large saucepan. Add the onions and sauté until softened. Add the flour, salt, garlic powder and ground pepper to the sautéed onions. Stir together to form a smooth paste. Once a paste has formed, start adding the milk in small amounts, stirring constantly to combine the flour mix and milk. Each time it thickens, add a little more milk until it has all been added. The final mixture should be thickened and bubbling. Pour the broth into the small saucepan. Bring to a boil, then drop to a simmer. Add the shredded carrot and chopped celery to the boiled broth. Simmer for 5 minutes, or until the vegetables have softened. Transfer the broth mix to the flour mix. Stir together to blend well. Add the shredded cheeses to this mixture and stir over a low heat, until melted in. The soup should be a thickened, liquid mixture. Do not boil the soup once the cheese has been added. Remove from the heat. Pour the soup into four different bowls. Finish with a few chopped chives as a garnish, if desired. French Cheese Soup Toast the stale bread slices. Spread butter over them. Sprinkle generously with the grated cheese. Set aside. Sauté the onion rings in a little of the olive oil. Remove from the heat and set aside. Make a single layer of the cheese-covered toast slices in the cast iron pot. Over this layer, arrange a layer of the sautéed onion rings. Then place another single layer of the bread pieces. Cover with chopped, peeled tomatoes. Finish with another layer of sautéed onions. Add a little bit more of the tomatoes and sprinkle in some more grated cheese. Gently press down on the mixture to make space for the stock. Then pour the stock into it through a carefully placed funnel. Pour very gently and carefully so as to cause the stock to go below the ingredients; the other ingredients should not be covered by the stock. Place the cast iron pot onto the stovetop. Do not cover. Allow to simmer for 30 minutes. Place in the oven and cook for one hour in a medium hot oven. Check now and then; add more stock if needed, using a funnel again. It is important to keep the level of stock constant. Remove from the oven. Serve into six different dishes, taking care not to swamp the ingredients in liquid. Serve immediately.
